unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Ad Campaigns: Type I Error
question_text: Suppose the CCO of a local fast food chain is considering two different advertising campaigns: One campaign focuses on low prices, while the other campaign focuses on great service. In the same large city, $15$ randomly selected stores within the chain focused on low prices, and another $15$ randomly selected stores within the chain focused on great service. The CCO hopes to determine if any significant difference exists between the effect of the two advertising campaigns. Describe a Type I error in this context and give consequences of a Type I error.

choices.text: Type I error: incorrectly identifying the campaign that focuses on low prices as a better when it is not.   Consequence: incorporating with a failed advertising campaign.
Type I error: incorrectly stating that the low prices campaign fails to increase sales.   Consequence: failing to see this campaign is helpful.
Type I error: incorrectly identifying the good service campaign as better when it really is not.   Consequence: incorporating with a failed advertising campaign.
Type I error: failing to determine a difference in sales that really existed.   Consequence: the company would miss out on the chance to increase sales by use of a better advertising campaign.

Type I error: determining there is a difference in campaign effectiveness, when in fact no difference exists.   Consequence: the company would incorporate a campaign but would not be overly successful in increasing sales with it.
